name: 1623_A. Robot Cleaner
description:
A robot cleaner is placed on the floor of a rectangle room, surrounded by walls. The floor consists of n rows and m columns. The rows of the floor are numbered from 1 to n from top to bottom, and columns of the floor are numbered from 1 to m from left to right. The cell on the intersection of the r-th row and the c-th column is denoted as (r,c). The initial position of the robot is (r_b, c_b).

In one second, the robot moves by dr rows and dc columns, that is, after one second, the robot moves from the cell (r, c) to (r + dr, c + dc). Initially dr = 1, dc = 1. If there is a vertical wall (the left or the right walls) in the movement direction, dc is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dc is -dc. And if there is a horizontal wall (the upper or lower walls), dr is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dr is -dr.

Each second (including the moment before the robot starts moving), the robot cleans every cell lying in the same row or the same column as its position. There is only one dirty cell at (r_d, c_d). The job of the robot is to clean that dirty cell.

<image> Illustration for the first example. The blue arc is the robot. The red star is the target dirty cell. Each second the robot cleans a row and a column, denoted by yellow stripes.

Given the floor size n and m, the robot's initial position (r_b, c_b) and the dirty cell's position (r_d, c_d), find the time for the robot to do its job.

Input

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4). Description of the test cases follows.

A test case consists of only one line, containing six integers n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, and c_d (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 100, 1 ≤ r_b, r_d ≤ n, 1 ≤ c_b, c_d ≤ m) — the sizes of the room, the initial position of the robot and the position of the dirt cell.

Output

For each test case, print an integer — the time for the robot to clean the dirty cell. We can show that the robot always cleans the dirty cell eventually.

Example

Input


5
10 10 6 1 2 8
10 10 9 9 1 1
9 8 5 6 2 1
6 9 2 2 5 8
2 2 1 1 2 1


Output


7
10
9
3
0

Note

In the first example, the floor has the size of 10× 10. The initial position of the robot is (6, 1) and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 8). See the illustration of this example in the problem statement.

In the second example, the floor is the same, but the initial position of the robot is now (9, 9), and the position of the dirty cell is (1, 1). In this example, the robot went straight to the dirty cell and clean it. 

<image>

In the third example, the floor has the size 9 × 8. The initial position of the robot is (5, 6), and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 1). 

<image>

In the fourth example, the floor has the size 6 × 9. The initial position of the robot is (2, 2) and the position of the dirty cell is (5, 8). 

<image>

In the last example, the robot was already standing in the same column as the dirty cell, so it can clean the cell right away.

A robot cleaner is placed on the floor of a rectangle room, surrounded by walls. The floor consists of n rows and m columns. The rows of the floor are numbered from 1 to n from top to bottom, and columns of the floor are numbered from 1 to m from left to right. The cell on the intersection of the r-th row and the c-th column is denoted as (r,c). The initial position of the robot is (r_b, c_b).

In one second, the robot moves by dr rows and dc columns, that is, after one second, the robot moves from the cell (r, c) to (r + dr, c + dc). Initially dr = 1, dc = 1. If there is a vertical wall (the left or the right walls) in the movement direction, dc is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dc is -dc. And if there is a horizontal wall (the upper or lower walls), dr is reflected before the movement, so the new value of dr is -dr.

Each second (including the moment before the robot starts moving), the robot cleans every cell lying in the same row or the same column as its position. There is only one dirty cell at (r_d, c_d). The job of the robot is to clean that dirty cell.

<image> Illustration for the first example. The blue arc is the robot. The red star is the target dirty cell. Each second the robot cleans a row and a column, denoted by yellow stripes.

Given the floor size n and m, the robot's initial position (r_b, c_b) and the dirty cell's position (r_d, c_d), find the time for the robot to do its job. Make sure to consider edge cases where the robot might start on or immediately adjacent to the dirty cell. The description should also account for scenarios where the robot reaches the boundaries and changes its direction due to reflection.

Input

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4). Description of the test cases follows.

A test case consists of only one line, containing six integers n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, and c_d (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 100, 1 ≤ r_b, r_d ≤ n, 1 ≤ c_b, c_d ≤ m) — the sizes of the room, the initial position of the robot and the position of the dirt cell.

Output

For each test case, print an integer — the time for the robot to clean the dirty cell. We can show that the robot always cleans the dirty cell eventually.

Input


5
10 10 6 1 2 8
10 10 9 9 1 1

7
10
9
3
0

In the fourth example, the floor has the size 6 × 9. The initial position of the robot is (2, 2) and the position of the dirty cell is (5, 8). 

<image>

In the last example, the robot was already standing in the same column as the dirty cell, so it can clean the cell right away.

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

def time_to_clean(n: int, m: int, r_b: int, c_b: int, r_d: int, c_d: int) -> int:
    """Calculate the time required for the robot to clean the dirty cell.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the room.
        m (int): Number of columns in the room.
        r_b (int): Initial row position of the robot.
        c_b (int): Initial column position of the robot.
        r_d (int): Row position of the dirty cell.
        c_d (int): Column position of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        int: Time required to clean the dirty cell.
    """
    # Initialize direction of movement
    dr, dc = 1, 1  # dr: row direction, dc: column direction
    time = 0

    while r_b != r_d or c_b != c_d:
        # Move the robot
        r_b += dr
        c_b += dc
        time += 1

        # Check for reflection on the walls
        if r_b == n-1 or r_b == 0:
            dr *= -1  # Reverse row direction
        if c_b == m-1 or c_b == 0:
            dc *= -1  # Reverse column direction

    return time

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    results = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d = map(int, input().split())
        result = time_to_clean(n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d)
        results.append(result)

    for res in results:
        print(res)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def time_to_clean(n: int, m: int, r_b: int, c_b: int, r_d: int, c_d: int) -> int:
    """Calculate the minimum time for the robot to reach the dirty cell.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the room.
        m (int): Number of columns in the room.
        r_b (int): Initial row position of the robot.
        c_b (int): Initial column position of the robot.
        r_d (int): Row position of the dirty cell.
        c_d (int): Column position of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        int: Minimum time to reach the dirty cell.
    """
    # Calculate the minimum steps required in both row and column directions
    row_steps = abs(r_d - r_b)
    col_steps = abs(c_d - c_b)
    
    # The time to reach the dirty cell is the maximum of the row and column steps
    return max(row_steps, col_steps)

def main():
    """Main function to read input, process each test case, and output results."""
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    
    # First line contains the number of test cases
    t = int(data[0])
    results = []
    
    # Process each test case
    for i in range(1, t + 1):
        n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d = map(int, data[i].split())
        result = time_to_clean(n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d)
        results.append(result)
    
    # Output results for each test case
    for res in results:
        print(res)

from typing import List, Tuple

def time_to_clean(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Calculate the time taken for the robot to clean the dirty cell for each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the room.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the room.
            - x (int): Initial row position of the robot.
            - y (int): Initial column position of the robot.
            - d_x (int): Row position of the dirty cell.
            - d_y (int): Column position of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of time taken for the robot to clean the dirty cell for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, m, x, y, d_x, d_y in test_cases:
        time = 0
        direction_x = 1  # Initial direction along x-axis
        direction_y = 1  # Initial direction along y-axis
        
        while (x != d_x) or (y != d_y):
            # Move the robot
            x += direction_x
            y += direction_y
            time += 1
            
            # Check for boundary collision and adjust direction
            if x == n or x == 1:
                direction_x *= -1
            if y == m or y == 1:
                direction_y *= -1
        
        results.append(time)
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to read input, process test cases, and output results."""
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    
    # Read each test case
    test_cases = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(t)]
    
    # Get results
    results = time_to_clean(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output results
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def time_to_clean(n: int, m: int, r_b: int, c_b: int, r_d: int, c_d: int) -> int:
    """Calculate the time required for the robot to clean the dirty cell.

    The robot moves diagonally and reflects off the room's boundaries.
    
    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the room.
        m (int): Number of columns in the room.
        r_b (int): Initial row position of the robot.
        c_b (int): Initial column position of the robot.
        r_d (int): Row position of the dirty cell.
        c_d (int): Column position of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        int: Time required to clean the dirty cell.
    """
    # Calculate the time to reach the dirty cell
    # The robot moves diagonally, so we need to calculate the time based on the
    # minimum number of steps required to reach the dirty cell in either direction.
    
    # Calculate the time to reach the dirty cell in row and column direction
    row_time = abs(r_d - r_b)
    col_time = abs(c_d - c_b)
    
    # The time to clean is the maximum of the two times because the robot moves diagonally
    return max(row_time, col_time)

def main():
    """Main function to read input and output the result."""
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(data[0])
    results = []
    for i in range(1, t + 1):
        n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d = map(int, data[i].split())
        result = time_to_clean(n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d)
        results.append(result)
    for res in results:
        print(res)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def time_to_clean(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Calculate the time taken for a robot to clean a dirty cell in a room.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]): Each test case contains:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the room.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the room.
            - rb (int): Starting row of the robot.
            - cb (int): Starting column of the robot.
            - rd (int): Row of the dirty cell.
            - cd (int): Column of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of times taken for each test case to clean the dirty cell.
    """
    results = []

    for case in test_cases:
        n, m, rb, cb, rd, cd = case
        time = 0
        dr, dc = 1, 1  # Initial direction: moving down and right

        while rb != rd or cb != cd:
            # Move the robot
            if rb == n:
                dr = -1  # Reflect off the bottom wall
            elif rb == 1:
                dr = 1  # Reflect off the top wall

            if cb == m:
                dc = -1  # Reflect off the right wall
            elif cb == 1:
                dc = 1  # Reflect off the left wall

            rb += dr
            cb += dc
            time += 1

        results.append(time)

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    # Read each test case
    test_cases = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(t)]
    # Get results
    results = time_to_clean(t, test_cases)
    # Output results
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def time_to_clean(n: int, m: int, r_b: int, c_b: int, r_d: int, c_d: int) -> int:
    """Calculate the time taken for the robot to clean the dirty cell.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the room.
        m (int): Number of columns in the room.
        r_b (int): Initial row position of the robot.
        c_b (int): Initial column position of the robot.
        r_d (int): Row position of the dirty cell.
        c_d (int): Column position of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        int: Time taken to clean the dirty cell.
    """
    # If the robot is already in the same row or column as the dirty cell
    if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
        return 0

    # Calculate the time to reach the dirty cell by moving in a straight line
    # and reflecting off walls if necessary
    row_distance = abs(r_d - r_b)
    col_distance = abs(c_d - c_b)

    # Calculate time considering reflections
    time_row = min(row_distance, 2 * (n - 1) - row_distance)
    time_col = min(col_distance, 2 * (m - 1) - col_distance)

    return min(time_row, time_col)

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t: int = int(input())
    results: List[int] = []

    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d = map(int, input().split())
        result = time_to_clean(n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d)
        results.append(result)

    for res in results:
        print(res)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def time_to_clean(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Calculate the time required for a robot to clean a dirty cell in a room.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]): Each test case contains:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the room.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the room.
            - rb (int): Initial row position of the robot.
            - cb (int): Initial column position of the robot.
            - rd (int): Row position of the dirty cell.
            - cd (int): Column position of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of times required for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for case in test_cases:
        n, m, rb, cb, rd, cd = case

        # Calculate the time to reach the dirty cell
        # The robot moves diagonally, so we need to calculate the time based on the
        # minimum number of steps required to reach either the row or column of the dirty cell.
        time_to_row = rd - rb if rd >= rb else 2 * n - rb - rd
        time_to_col = cd - cb if cd >= cb else 2 * m - cb - cd

        # The time to clean the dirty cell is the minimum of the two times calculated
        time_to_clean = min(time_to_row, time_to_col)

        results.append(time_to_clean)

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(t)]
    results = time_to_clean(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def time_to_clean(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Calculate the time required for the robot to clean the dirty cell in each test case.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the room.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the room.
            - x (int): Starting row position of the robot.
            - y (int): Starting column position of the robot.
            - d_x (int): Row position of the dirty cell.
            - d_y (int): Column position of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of times required to clean the dirty cell for each test case.
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, m, x, y, d_x, d_y in test_cases:
        # Calculate the minimum steps required to align either the row or column with the dirty cell
        row_steps = abs(d_x - x)
        col_steps = abs(d_y - y)
        
        # The robot moves diagonally, so the time to clean is the maximum of row_steps and col_steps
        time_to_clean = max(row_steps, col_steps)
        
        results.append(time_to_clean)
    
    return results

# Input interface
import sys
input = sys.stdin.read

    data = input().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = [tuple(map(int, line.split())) for line in data[1:t+1]]
    
    # Output results
    results = time_to_clean(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def time_to_clean(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]) -> List[int]:
    """Calculate the minimum time for a robot to reach a dirty cell in a room.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, int, int, int]]): Each test case contains:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the room.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the room.
            - r_b (int): Initial row position of the robot.
            - c_b (int): Initial column position of the robot.
            - r_d (int): Row position of the dirty cell.
            - c_d (int): Column position of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        List[int]: List of minimum times for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d in test_cases:
        # Calculate the time to reach the dirty cell
        # The robot moves diagonally, so we need to consider the time to align with the dirty cell's row or column
        time_to_row = abs(r_d - r_b)
        time_to_col = abs(c_d - c_b)

        # The robot can move diagonally, so the time is the maximum of the two
        min_time = max(time_to_row, time_to_col)

        results.append(min_time)

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = [tuple(map(int, input(): ").split())) for _ in range(t)]
    results = time_to_clean(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
import sys

def time_to_clean(n: int, m: int, r_b: int, c_b: int, r_d: int, c_d: int) -> int:
    """Calculate the time it takes for the robot to clean the dirty cell.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        r_b (int): Starting row of the robot.
        c_b (int): Starting column of the robot.
        r_d (int): Row of the dirty cell.
        c_d (int): Column of the dirty cell.

    Returns:
        int: Time taken to clean the dirty cell.
    """
    # Initial direction of movement
    dr, dc = 1, 1
    time = 0

    while True:
        # Check if the robot is at the dirty cell
        if r_b == r_d or c_b == c_d:
            return time

        # Move the robot
        r_b += dr
        c_b += dc
        time += 1

        # Check for wall collisions and change direction if needed
        if r_b == 1 or r_b == n:
            dr *= -1
        if c_b == 1 or c_b == m:
            dc *= -1

def main():
    """Main function to read input, process each test case, and output results."""
    input_data = sys.stdin.read().strip().split('\n')
    t = int(input_data[0])
    results = []

    for i in range(1, t + 1):
        n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d = map(int, input_data[i].split())
        result = time_to_clean(n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, c_d)
        results.append(result)

    for res in results:
        print(res)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
plans:
requirement analysis:
The problem requires simulating the movement of a robot cleaner in a bounded rectangular room. The robot moves diagonally and reflects off walls, changing its direction. The task is to determine the time it takes for the robot to clean a specific dirty cell, considering its initial position and the room's dimensions. The solution must efficiently handle up to 10,000 test cases, each with room dimensions up to 100x100.
requirement pool:
- Implement the robot's movement and reflection logic.

We will implement a simulation of the robot's movement in a bounded rectangular room using basic arithmetic operations to handle the reflection logic. The solution will iterate over each test case, simulating the robot's movement until it cleans the dirty cell. Given the constraints, the approach will focus on efficient computation without unnecessary complexity, ensuring it handles up to 10,000 test cases efficiently.
requirement analysis:
The problem requires simulating the movement of a robot cleaner in a bounded rectangular room. The robot moves diagonally and reflects off walls, cleaning the row and column it occupies each second. The task is to determine the time taken for the robot to clean a specific dirty cell. The solution must handle multiple test cases efficiently, considering the constraints on room size and number of test cases.

The robot moves diagonally, and we need to calculate the time it takes to reach the dirty cell by considering the minimum number of steps required in both row and column directions. We will use simple arithmetic to determine the time based on the initial and target positions, and the room's dimensions. This approach ensures efficiency even with the maximum constraints.

We will simulate the robot's movement on a grid, taking into account the reflections off the walls. The robot will move in a straight line, changing direction when it hits a wall. The key challenge is to efficiently calculate the time it takes for the robot to clean the dirty cell, considering the robot cleans all cells in the same row and column as it moves. We will use a simple loop to simulate the robot's movement and check if the dirty cell is cleaned at each step. Given the constraints, this approach will be efficient enough.
examples:
Input

Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4). Description of the test cases follows.

A test case consists of only one line, containing six integers n, m, r_b, c_b, r_d, and c_d (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 100, 1 ≤ r_b, r_d ≤ n, 1 ≤ c_b, c_d ≤ m) — the sizes of the room, the initial position of the robot and the position of the dirt cell.

Output

For each test case, print an integer — the time for the robot to clean the dirty cell. We can show that the robot always cleans the dirty cell eventually.

Example

Input


5
10 10 6 1 2 8
10 10 9 9 1 1
9 8 5 6 2 1
6 9 2 2 5 8
2 2 1 1 2 1


Output


7
10
9
3
0

Note

In the first example, the floor has the size of 10× 10. The initial position of the robot is (6, 1) and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 8). See the illustration of this example in the problem statement.

In the second example, the floor is the same, but the initial position of the robot is now (9, 9), and the position of the dirty cell is (1, 1). In this example, the robot went straight to the dirty cell and clean it. 

<image>

In the third example, the floor has the size 9 × 8. The initial position of the robot is (5, 6), and the position of the dirty cell is (2, 1). 

<image>

In the fourth example, the floor has the size 6 × 9. The initial position of the robot is (2, 2) and the position of the dirty cell is (5, 8). 

<image>

In the last example, the robot was already standing in the same column as the dirty cell, so it can clean the cell right away.
